There came a blazing remark about the "final" keyword being the most
counterproductive keyword in Java, I don't remember who it was.  Let me
offer some of my insight...

I particularly like final on member variables.  I am a BIG fan of
creating immutable objects -- I like for my objects to be in a sane
state when they are created.  Having to set any number of things on them
before being able to use them smells bad to me. --Personal tastes
perhaps.  That doesn't mean I don't ever use setters, it's just that
avoid them like the plague, but sometimes they catch me.

I tend to like final on classes.  Here are some reasons:
  -- I don't see the the real strength of OOP being inheritance
  -- putting final on a class makes me think twice when I want to
     extend from it.  "Is the "IS-A" relationship right in this
     case or am I just being lazy?"
  -- others?? Maybe, but I don't have the brain power right now to
     list them.

I don't usually put final on methods.  If they are public in any sense
of the word (default, protected, public) then they are part of the
public contract.  If the class is extended the subclass should have all
the right to override that functionality.  I tend to think that if it
hurts too much for the subclass to override a method it indicates one of
two things: the subclass probably shouldn't be there, refactor to a
Delegate, _OR_ the method shouldn't be in the base class, refactor it to
the proper class.

Just my $0.05...

=jason
